paragraphs.title: The Opposite
paragraphs.p: We refer to the number -5 by the name negative 5. The word negative always refers to things less than zero. So, what should we call the expression -N?

If N is a variable (or an unknown quantity), then it may not make sense to say negative N. If N is a positive number, then this would be fine, but if N is a negative number, then -N would be positive. No matter whether N is positive or negative to begin with, the expression -N will have the opposite sign of N.
Therefore, we will call -N the oppositeopposite of N.
This is particularly useful when we don't know if a variable is positive or negative.

subsection.title: The transformation y = -f(x)
subsection.p: Suppose f is a function. If f(-5) is a positive number, then -f(-5) will be negative, and if f(2) is a negative number, then -f(2) will be positive.
The same input is used, but the outputs are opposites.
In general, whatever output values f(x) has, the transformation y = -f(x) will have the opposite output values.

subsection.title: The transformation y = f(-x)
subsection.p: For a function g(x), the transformation g(-x) does something else.
If you wanted to evaluate g(-x) when x = 4, you would really be evaluating g(-4). Or, if you wanted to evaluate g(-x) when x = -9, you would really be evaluating g(9).
The transformation g(-x) evaluates the function g(x) at the opposite input.

statement.p: Suppose h(5) = 9 and h(-5) = 13 for some function h.

li.p: What point must be on the graph of y = h(x)?
Answer:
What point must be on the graph of y = h(-x)?
answer:

hint.p: A point on the graph of y = h(-x) is found by first choosing an x-value. The y-coordinate of the point is found by evaluating the function h at the opposite of the x-value you chose.

solution.p: If h(5) = 9 and h(-5) = 13, then the graph of y = h(x) has the points (5, 9) and (-5, 13).
The graph of y = h(-x) would have reflections of these points over the y-axis: (5, 13) and (-5, 9)

li.p: The function g(x) is a reflection of f(x) over the x-axis, making all of the outputs of those functions opposites of each other.

Therefore, h(x) \amp= f(-x) \amp= (-x+)^4
